pages.text: Tegopelte comes from the Middle Cambrian, with fossils found in the Burgess Shale, Canada. It is a small, soft-bodied trilobitomorph, growing up to 28 cm in lengeth. Despite its small size, it was fairly large for Cambrian arthropods. It was also once classified as a trilobite, although this is no longer the case, this is first due to the distinct morphological differences to true trilobites, like the large undivided carapace being an example. We also know of

there trackways from the Kicking Horse Shale within the Burgess Shale that could be assigned to Tegopelte, suggesting they were a benthic animal, and also suggested they could move fairly quickly along the seafloor and take tight turns, as well as control their speed and slow themselves down at time.
The generic name derives from the Greek words 'tegos', to mean 'tile'; and 'pelte', to mean 'leather-shield'. The specific name derives directly from the Greek word 'gigas', to mean 'giant'.
